##  Not all Bluetooth headphones are made equal: here's our pick of the very
best you can buy in 2020

Bluetooth headphones have become increasingly important since phone
manufacturers began removing the 3.5mm socket from their handsets. Quality has
been steadily improving and the gap between Bluetooth and wireless headphones
has closed significantly.

With so much choice, picking the right Bluetooth headphones can be tough.
There are hundreds of different models available, from compact in-ear
headphones for sport and exercise to larger on- and over-ear headphones that
provide additional features such as longer battery life and improved noise
cancellation.

Below, you'll find our pick of the best in three simple categories: best over-
ear, best on-ear and best in-ear Bluetooth headphones. If you're not sure
which is for you, read our buyer's guide below. If you want to get into the
details, scroll past the guide and you'll find the reviews lower down the
page.

### How to pick the best Bluetooth headphones for you

#### What types of Bluetooth headphones are there?

If convenience is your number-one priority, a set of compact **in-ear
headphones** is your best option. These fit inside your ear canal and the
earpieces can be connected by thin wiring that goes around your neck or a
thicker neckband (neckbuds). They can even be completely wire-free in the case
of true wireless earbuds. Given their lightweight these styles of in-ear
headphones are typically the best choice for running and other forms of
exercise. They're also very easily transported, which makes them a great
choice for general day-to-day use. The downsides are that they're generally
less comfortable to wear for longer periods of time and, as they're smaller,
battery life often lags behind larger headphones. That battery issue can be
overcome by choosing a pair of true wireless headphones, which typically come
with a portable charging case.

See related

[Best over-ear headphones 2020: The best Bluetooth, noise-cancelling and wired

[Best noise-cancelling headphones 2020: The best ANC headphones you can
buy](/headphones/1406074/best-noise-cancelling-anc-headphones)

For many, **on-ear and over-ear headphones** are preferable both in terms of
comfort and sound. These headphones feature earcups which either create a seal
over your ears or rest on top of them. The larger size of the headphones
allows them to contain bigger batteries and features such as active noise
cancellation (ANC) are more commonplace on pricier sets. ANC uses in-built
microphones to listen to the outside noise and remove it from the music you're
listening to – perfect for noisy commutes or transatlantic flights.

#### How much should I spend?

You can pick up a pair of **in-ear** Bluetooth headphones for as little as £30
and these can provide surprisingly good sound quality. We’ve even seen some at
this price with the high-quality aptX version of Bluetooth, which is well
worth having if your smartphone or other devices also support aptX. However,
some of the cheaper headphones may lack a built-in microphone for hands-free
calls, or have limited battery life, so it's worth checking the manufacturer's
specifications before making a decision.

 **READ NEXT:[The best cheap headphones to buy](/headphones/1405724/best-
cheap-budget-headphones-earphones-uk "best cheap headphones")**

Above £50, you’ll get better audio quality as well as additional features such
as water and sweat-resistance for sporty people, and a wider selection of tips
for the earpieces to provide a comfy, secure fit. However, you’ll probably
need to step up to £100 or more to get really good sound from in-ear
headphones, including the powerful bass that many people seem to prefer for
dance tracks or getting motivated at the gym.

You can also get some very respectable **on-ear and over-ear** Bluetooth
headphones for less than £50, and while build quality will tend to be fairly
plasticky, there are some good options in our list below. If you have a little
wiggle room in your budget, it's worth paying a little more for a set of
headphones that provide better audio quality and sturdy design.

The £100 mark is also where other features, such as noise-cancellation start
to appear as well (although the best noise-cancelling headphones can still
cost upwards of £250). You'll often get additional accessories, such as a
carrying case, or audio cables that allow you to use them as ordinary wired
headphones if the battery runs flat.

At around £150 to £200, you can expect really good sound quality and powerful
bass. Spend even more, and you'll get great design and stunning sound quality
as standard – and the very best active noise cancellation technology on the
market.

"best wireless earbuds")**

## The best over-ear Bluetooth headphones to buy in 2020

 **Why you should consider over-ear headphones:** they provide the best
comfort and isolation and, depending on your budget, the best sound over
wireless, too.

armour when it comes to their comfort, sound or noise-cancelling capabilities.
However, the OneOdio A10 manages to get each of those aspects right, with its
only real weakness being a lack of support for the aptX codec that allows for
24-bit streaming.

The A10’s ANC is particularly effective at blocking out low-end frequencies
and the 40mm drivers deliver impressive sound with a warm and well-balanced
signature. Their reproduction of bass is a little on the woolly side but
there’s plenty of detail across the full frequency spectrum.

You also get a surprising number of accessories given the highly competitive
price. Included in the box is a sturdy carrying case, a USB-C to 3.5mm cable,
a USB-A to USB-C charging cable and a 3.5mm x 2 aircraft adapter.

### Audio Technica ATH-DSR9BT: Astonishing sound but seriously expensive

 **Price:** £330 | **[Buy now from
Amazon](https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B06XYZB4VQ?&tag=experevi-21&ascsubtag=1405124)**[  
](https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B06XYZB4VQ?&tag=experevi-21&ascsubtag=1405124)

[
![](https://cdn2.expertreviews.co.uk/sites/expertreviews/files/styles/er_main_wide/public/2018/03/audio_technica_dsr9bt_review_lead_shot_0.jpg?itok=csUUjIY5)](https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B06XYZB4VQ?&tag=experevi-21&ascsubtag=1405124)

The Audio-Technica ATH-DSR9BT are among the most expensive set of Bluetooth
headphones you'll find on the market. These are made by, and designed for,
audiophiles: they support aptX HD and have their own chipset to playback the
digital sound. See, unlike most headphones that use a DAC to decode the 1s and
0s, the [ATH-DSR9BT retain the same digital signal](https://blog.audio-
technica.com/technology-behind-ath-dsr7bt-ath-dsr9bt-headphones/) from your
source and, therefore, mitigate the loss of audio quality over wireless.

It's really smart stuff, but ultimately, it's the headphone's sound quality
that really impresses. It has a balanced, accurate sound throughout the entire
frequency range. Aside from its sonic capabilities, the headphones are well
built and look terrific, too. If you have around £430 to splurge out on a set
